This entire course is a bit redundant. I know we're getting foundational information, but then we shouldn't be OVERfed with information and tested so difficultly on the content. Would've liked more good quality content on health communication.

This course was EXTREMELY POORLY CONDUCTED. I've heard non-stop complaints about this course since the beginning of the semester. How can you have 3 completely different subjects covered in a single course? They say it's for accreditation but this course was an absolute waste of time and money. Individual assignments were not helpful in understanding course material and the group assignments made me feel like I was back in middle school. The course wanted to emphasize systems thinking and group collaboration but 70% of this course is individual work. Over the semester, this course kept changing, which made it difficult to prepare for the final. Individual assignment questions were very unfair. I prepared so much for them through studying the lecture slides, reading papers, and even watching Youtube videos. My preparation didn't help at all. The individual assignments also included questions about epidemiology, which put so many students at a disadvantage if they had not reviewed concepts from Epi 1 from first semester. They really should have made this course online to save time and frustration.

strength: the course cover different fields of knowledge, provide interesting topics on major health threats. 
weakness: students need spend much more time on the course than expected.

Strengths: Covered relevant topics that all public health professionals should be able to talk about even if it's not your area of expertise. The instructors tried to make it more interactive, so people felt responsible to be there for their team. 

The course was very disorganized. This caused me a lot of anxiety when trying to plan out my work and study schedule. There needs to be more consistency between modules, so we can learn to know what to expect.

This was the most unorganized class I have taken at YSPH and oftentimes made me feel overwhelmed and confused. 

Weaknesses:
- Unorganized Canvas site
- Did not follow Syllabus 
- Too many assignments (3 assignments per module + final was overwhelming) 
- Poorly utilized class time (blocked out 1 hour and 50 minutes/ 2 x a week ], yet all assignments were given other days of the week)
- Harkness auditorium is not conducive for group work 
- Lack of clarity on how to prepare for individual assignments 
- Assessments did not reflect material taught in class
- Assigned seating; I was forced to sit in the back of a crowded auditorium which was not conducive to learning 

Strengths:
- Engaging reading 
- Breakout sessions were the most meaning experiences
This course was completely disorganized and random. The topics covered, although important, had too many things for one class which led to a lot of information and they demanded expertise in each.
variety of topics, important ones, but a large crowd (sometimes unmanagable)

Honestly? This class was a mess. I feel like it was YSPH's attempt to simply meet CEPH accreditation requirements, and as someone studying neither AMR, obesity, nor climate change (and as someone conscious of other MHTs, like those related to socioeconomic status), I found the class incredibly disappointing.

Clearly attention was given to the structure of the course, but the end concept didn't translate (at all). It often felt like the equivalent of an online class, and I did not come to this program to have that experience. The individual exams felt more like standardized tests (i.e. knowing how to "read between the lines" of test questions) than assessments of my understanding of the course material (i.e. pulling from content of course lectures). I never felt properly equipped to know how to study for these exams.

Forcing students to work together in pre-assigned groups also created a lot of problems given the disparity between maturity levels and professional experience prior to the program. While my group managed to find a groove by the final assignment, we faced a lot of stressful and frustrating problems throughout the better part of the semester.

Expectations on the final (whether it would be online, in person, etc) were unclear until the end of the semester, and I still don't feel confident in my understanding of course material (or how the exam will be structured). Example questions or study guides would have been appreciated.

This course was all over the place. The climate change module seemed well thought out and planned. The leadership lectures and groups seemed out of place. The leadership reflections seemed like busywork, especially for advanced professional students. There was little substantive feedback on group assignments and much of it seemed like busywork. The negotiation workshop was good and can be improved as an example of public health in practice. Not having the slides before lecture inhibited my learning.

This class was poorly designed. Three very different professors. Assessments and expectations changed throughout the semester. None of it seemed cohesive. Just a mess thrown together. I don't like feeling like a guinea pig in grad school, but that's what this course has felt like.

This is a well-intentioned course. I appreciated the opportunity to learn from different professors and engage with various public health topics. I enjoyed the fact that the course took a different approach than any other class I have taken. There were a few bumps in the road. I understand that there are generally hiccups when running a course for the first time. I enjoyed working with my peers in our group throughout the semester, but I believe there should be a group evaluation at the end of the semester. Some group members were more engaged than others, and I think it would be fair to award students participant points based on their peers' evaluations. Also, there were many assignments, and I think the class could have benefitted from some more clarity about deadlines and expectations. Overall, I enjoyed the different interactive assignments (debate, obesity working problem).

This was an extremely disorganized course that was not catered toward the entire first-year class by any means. Many of the topics necessitated far more than a basic understanding of biology-- as someone in the Policy department, many of the scientific rhetoric went right over my head and there were no opportunities for rudimentary review or further reading to establish a baseline understanding of what was being discussed. I do not doubt the brilliance of the professors who taught the course, but they clearly assumed that all students would have a much more in-depth scientific background than I and many of my peers felt we have to tackle the material in this course. 

Professor Dubrow, notably, did the best job at establishing context for the Climate Change module, thanks to choosing accessible yet interesting readings and sharing his instructional climate change videos with us. 

I enjoyed the group I was matched with and feel lucky to have the group members I did, but felt that requiring us to sit in our groups for every lecture was overbearing. Attendance was also taken for every single lecture, which I also felt was overboard, especially in the greater context of YSPH classes which (in my experience) trust students to do their work and show up to class, but also understand that sometimes conflicts arise, that we may not want to sit in the same seat with the same people for every class, nor that being monitored by a TA actually will increase the understanding of a class overall.

The course was really poorly organized. Everything changed on the go.
Teaching was really poor for the climate change module. Information was repetitive.
The place assigned for the course was not appropriate to work in groups, as the instructors proposed.
The group work was really hard and there were notable differences in participation and time investment for the assignments among different people in the group.

The course has a lot of potential--the modules were all about interesting and relevant topics, and I like group discussion. However, the auditorium was not conducive for group work. The lectures were kind of bland and I had trouble paying attention; they could have been more engaging. Overall, it felt poorly organized. The exams did not reflect the content covered throughout the year and sometimes it was hard to pin down what I actually learned. My engagement with the class decreased over time because I felt more and more frustrated and was not learning much.

I am truly disappointed in this class. It was very much an epidemiology class, but was marketed to be interdisciplinary. As a health policy student, it felt completely inapplicable to my specialization. The tests were tremendously difficult and the group assignments non-sensical and incredibly frustrating - because we were split into groups to work on group assignments, it seemed that the instructors wanted us to collaborate as a team. However, groups who delegated the assignments to the team leaders seemed to get better scores (ie, rewarded for not working as a group on a group project). It seems like the class was meant to check "capabilities" boxes, so it was very disjointed. I feel robbed out of a class this semester - when the program is so short, every credit counts. I don't feel like I learned enough applicable or useful information to justify having to take this class, and wish I could've spent this time in a class I could've made use of.

This course felt very disjointed and disorganized. I felt as though I was taking 3 different classes (climate change, antimicrobial resistance, and obesity). It was challenging to grasp the material when we were changing gears so quickly. Additionally, expectations for the course were not clear. During the climate change module, we had advanced notice of the group/individual assignment and were able to plan ahead. For the AMR and obesity modules, however, the assignments were released very close to the deadline. I felt as though these group assignments were very rushed. The dates for individual assignments also deviated from the syllabus and there was very short advanced notice. Sitting with your group each class is also challenging and contributed to the disorganization of the course. People were often climbing over each other in the auditorium and discussions were difficult in this setting. I think that having lecture followed by smaller sections for group work (in a classroom) would be beneficial. Finally, working in groups can be a strength, but I believe the course emphasized this component too heavily (sitting together in class, three group assignments, and several group activities). Overall I had a positive experience with my group, but many other classmates struggled taking on much more work while their group members were absent or unwilling to help.

Strengths- I came to enjoy the climate change model and while no one will accuse Dr. Dubrow of being overly animated, he knows his stuff.

Weaknesses- quite frankly, just about everything else in this class. I understand this was a new 'concept' class and the topics are required through the Public Health Accreditation, but this class needs to be seriously re-thought. The AMR module was so technical and detailed, I overhead some Dr's in the class commenting that it was more detailed than they got in medical school. The obesity module was ok and the leadership reflections were forced hype of the worst kind.  

The biggest issue is that the professors were really ambitious thinking that they were going to get an entire lecture hall to behave like a small seminar.

I think in theory the course could have been amazing- I loved the concept of topic-based modules and rotating professors. The team-based work was also a great idea. However, in application the course was unfortunately a bit of a disaster. There was no accountability for group members, so people often ended up just not coming to class or not doing any work whatsoever for group assignments. Perhaps a QR code or a short prompt for students to complete would be helpful in order to track attendance. It was also just so difficult logistically to have discussions in the middle of class that were actually productive when we were spread out so much and in such a loud environment. I really enjoyed the idea behind some of the in-class assignments, like the causal loop diagrams or intervention design, but I feel like I didn't actually gain anything from them because they were so rushed with little thought put in due to pressure to simply get something in. 

I think ultimately a lot of the issues stemmed from it just being too big of a class to be conducive to the meaningful goals of the course.  I know this would be more of a time commitment for the professors because they would need to teach the whole semester rather than just one module, but one idea is to split the class into 3 separate groups that would rotate through modules throughout the semester (with one starting in obesity, one starting in climate change, and one starting in AMR). This way, the class size would at least be cut down by 2/3 for the immediate learning environment. It could also be good to break the 2 lectures a week into two themes: the first topic-based and the second activity-based to make the in-class activities more impactful.

The course is a combination of parts that may not be useful for biostatistics student. The contents of course is fragmented. The intent for the course is good: to let public health student know more about the public health issues. However, the components of the course is not to let student know a broad picture but some soecific points, which is not as efficient because of too much biological language which leads to high difficulty for non-biology-related major students. The content of leadership,!systematic thinking as well as negotiations are left superficially and do not help.

I really didn't like this course. It felt like it had been thrown together while I liked each professor of the course individually, I felt very uninterested in the course as a whole. I would have appreciated having the option to replace this course with a relevant elective that gave more specialized, in depth knowledge about MHT than this course provided. It was choppy and the evaluations for student learning were unusual to say the least  the online open-book quizzes were marginally representative of the material discussed in class (I felt like the AMR quiz was designed for students in EMD with a more advanced understanding of AMR than most). I think the climate change module was the most interesting/well-organized of the three. The assignments felt like busy work. And the break out sessions didn't help to make the class (of 200+) feel more intimate. In fact, the group projects were sophomoric and rather boring. But if CEPH needed it for our accreditation, then I guess YSPH did its job. Since the class is a required course, I guess stating that "I wouldn't recommend this course" doesn't really matter. Just finish it/try to enjoy. I hope they fix some of the kinks before next year.
This course was not great...it was poorly designed and organized, had way too many assignments, and in-class group work.

Strengths: Summary of critical issues in the field of public health (climate change, antimicrobial resistance, and obesity) condensed into a one-semester course. 

Weaknesses: Each module was very rushed, and taught by professors who are incredibly knowledgable in their respective fields, which unfortunately led to a deeper than necessary focus on niche topics more than on a broader understanding of the complexities of the issues. Furthermore, group work was incredibly frustrating to complete due to the lack of an attendance policy. The attempts to focus on leadership development and group work would be much more effective if attendance were required.

I was excited for this course; however, it was a mess from the beginning. For one, the syllabus is unorganized and confusing. I expected to learn big picture ideas from each of the modules, but the lecturers instead presented very specific topics that I did not think were necessary. The first two modules were okay, but I do not think that evaluating a research paper is conducive to learning about climate change. The third module felt like a waste of time. I feel like by tuition dollars were wasted in this course, and I expect something better from an institution like Yale.

This class has so many weaknesses. It was really disorganized, the syllabus was not adhered to at all, the professors seemed as confused about the direction of the course as the students. The class just had too much going on: negations, debates, writing policy briefs one week and then health communication plans the next. It didn't feel like we were learning, just being shuffled around from busy-work to busy-activities. I didn't feel challenged by the course, just irritated. And the individual assessments were all out of left-field. Getting the correct answer was a matter of semantics, rather than a matter of knowing the material. The structure of this class really needs some work.
It was a horribly executed course. Instructors did not take into consideration the scope and point of the course.

I enjoyed the course material and topics, however, the organization of it made it difficult to grasp main concepts. 

The modules may need to cover more basics for those who do not have a background in the subject. 

Group essays were not an enjoyable experience.

Overall, this was a waste of time. And at that, a stressful and time consuming waste. The biggest areas for improvement are as follows:
1) Professors did not seem to know what our background is. In particular, the AMR professor and obesity to some extent, seemed to think we had an understanding of the basics of what they were talking about. I DID NOT. most people in the policy department did not. No attempt was made to bridge this gap. Overly technical, and little understanding of what the takeaways are supposed to be. To me (policy bias, I know.), a class like this should be aimed at helping us to understand potential solution to all of these major health threats, and this was accomplished in NONE of these classes. Obesity and AMR are naturally interesting- over fixation on random things like biomarkers made this class completely useless.
2) The assessments were TERRIBLE and unfair. They did NOT test the material, and there was no way to improve. For AMR, extremely technical language was used, and it was not uncommon for me to only understand about 1/10 words of each question. A more thorough assessment of the non-emd students' background was needed. For me to improve my performance on these assignments, I would just have to take Epi 2... most of the questions could NOT be answered by what we learned in this class alone.
3) I was not blessed with a group that has natural writing skills, meaning I ended up doing about 3x as much work as everyone else. They'll probably get a better overall grade than me. This class does not balance strengths and weaknesses. If you are a good writer but don't know much about biology or epi (I.e. most of the policy department), you end up having to do all the work for everyone else but then left on your own on these ridiculous individual assignments. I reported in every single "leadership evaluation" thing that I was doing a hugely disproportionate amount of my groups work. Even the one kid who literally did not contribute to a single group assignment will probably get a better grade than me overall, despite putting in like 1/20th of the work.
the course is not well structured. many of friends also complain that this course adds very little value to the MPH curriculum.
I don't think this course has strong value added to MPH students
This course was incredibly poorly designed and I did not walk away with any information. The class size needs to be smaller and not as much information needs to be combined into one course.
disorganized

Strength: Halal food at the Carts outside of YSM.
Weaknesses: Everything else.
Improvement: Cancel it.
Poor overall organization and required students attendance even when sick or needed to be away.

An absolute dumpster fire. The instructors should be paying the students for having to suffer as guinea pigs through this godawful experiment. It was a poorly designed and confusing course. The instructors seemed to be bottom of the barrel and the assignments were arbitrarily graded. The exams were far too difficult, even for someone paying attention in class. The group project aspect of the course was a nuisance but at least there were people you could commiserate with. The TF team seemed equally as frustrated. This was just a perfect example of a course gone wrong. 

Weaknesses:
Part 0: The leadership portion of the course was confusing. I understood what it was trying to do but it wasn't effective. The instructor was not really engaging. The lecture itself was all over the place. Just a mess. 

Part 1: During the climate change module, we learned that climate change was leading to excessive drying in some parts of the world. What *wasn't* mentioned in class was that the professor's lectures were in fact the driest things on Earth. The professor was just not the most engaging personality. And the "supplemental videos" were unnecessary. If you can't fit all the information you got into the lecture time then rethink your portion of the course. The group assignment was really out of left field and not related to the course.  It didn't help us engage with the material. This was a horrible way to begin the course. It had the potential to be really interesting but the delivery fell flat. 

Part 2: Melinda was fine. She was probably the best professor. But she just had this aura of being "over it." Which is fine, because we were too. The AMR stuff was the most interesting and most engaging portion of the course. The interactive components like the debate and negotiation were not really needed (they felt thrown in) but they were a welcome break from lecture.

Part 3: This part was an ABSOLUTE MESS. The lecture slides were made by a third grader. The instructor was way too all over the place. I could not follow her. She just had way too much to say about nothing at all. I just left this portion of the course feeling tired by all of the tomfoolery that had occurred throughout the entire semester. The group assignment was horribly misguided and didn't help me learn any new skills or push myself. It was just busy work. This was probably the worst part of the course based on content. 

This was just a horrible class. Absolutely no merits.

I truly cannot put into words how poorly organized this course was and am not going to waste my time any further providing feedback. The organizers know better and need to do better. The students that were forced to take this class should get a tuition reimbursement.

I think they tried to cover too many things in one course. You can't have a course that includes leadership, systems thinking, health communications, climate change, AMR, and obesity. Those are all huge topics that could all be a course in themselves. I don't feel like I gained any real knowledge from the course, except for some basic understanding of the three main topics. I would honestly have preferred to take a whole class on one of these subjects than taking a course that tried to fit in too many topics.
Garbage course. Better for a student to take a course in one of the three modules separately than taking this overview of all three with minimal knowledge.
not interested in this topic, have no idea why we make it a core class.

The course was based on a great premise. I definitely like the idea of having students work in an interdisciplinary team to tackle major public health issues. However, the course did not live up to its potential. The three professors were definitely intelligent and experts in their respective niche fields, but I think they got lost in the details and did not communicate the material well for a broader public health audience. Not all students in the class were in EMD or EHS or CDE or had a background in biology or biochemistry to understand the nitty gritty details of antimicrobial resistance or the specific pathogen or antibiotics for certain strains. Requiring students without a biology background or those in HP or HCM to sit through dry lectures on horizontal gene transfer is absolutely ridiculous. I understand that knowing a bit of biology is helpful, but what is the stretch from memorizing different antigens or different types of green house gases or different types of fat to passing legislation to address these major health threats from a structural approach? The course's idea was great, but it should not turn into a biology course and in the end give students zero tangible skills to apply in future public health settings (i.e. not everyone will work in a lab setting to figure out virus strains). Also, I was disappointed that group assignments were only 10% of our grade each while the multiple choice format final was of 30%. These multiple choice questions were on nitty gritty details about the material that added little value to our development (anyone could just look things up on Google). On the other hand, we spent a lot of time and energy on group assignments, which I found to be more meaningful as they actually required us to think critically. I wish an assignment like that could have been something we all worked on throughout the semester, not just a few weeks. The course should also give students the option to choose a topic of their interest and come up with an action plan for it. I think these assignments are more meaning and have more practical implications. Again, I think the course has a lot of potential; it just needs to be made more general for a wider public health audience and focuses on expanding students' skillsets, not their knowledge of the nitty gritty details of science. This is a course for a Master's degree, which is a professional degree, so the course should focus on developing tangible skills. I think it was a bit ridiculous to force students to follow text book principles of leadership and followership whereas these dynamics typically develop organically in the real world. While I understand that the school needs to meet certain requirements for accreditation purposes, I think that instead of treating leadership as if it was a box to be checked, the school should require all core classes or certain departmental courses to have a group work component in the syllabi. That way students aren't forced to carry a label of being a leader or a follower and instead just developing their own work dynamics on something tangible and applicable. Also, requiring students to take this course their first year for accreditation purposes simply makes no sense when students still graduate from Yale with the course on their transcript no matter what. It was demoralizing for students to have taken this class where they didn't learn any valuable new skills due to the way it was executed; MPH is a professional degree, and we could have taken a skills-based class in place of this to boost our skillset to be competitive in our internship search. There should be a balance between providing students knowledge and providing students skills. Lastly, I found it ironic that while the course urged students to think of major health threats from a big picture perspective (case in point: the last lecture on system thinking wrapped everything up and drove this point home), the MC assignments were on the nitty gritty details.

This was truly the worst course I've ever taken. I think I was lost the entirety of the course. I felt that for a course that was supposed to synthesize the core from the previous semester, the modules asked for a very niche understanding of content, especially AMR. Additionally, instead of fostering collaboration by assigning groups, this came across more of micro-management (i.e. sit with your groups in lecture). I felt that the space (lecture hall) wasn't conducive to the type of conversation the instructors intended. While in theory the course had all the components to be great (collaboration, synthesis, modular structure), but practice was a whole other story. I think it was doing to much and caused a lot of confusion and dread near 3PM on Tuesdays and Thursdays

Scattered, poorly organized
Inconsistency across syllabus and now course was deliveredgood in principle, bad in execution
Course expectations not clearly defined beforehand, up to module leaderassignments varied greatly in difficulty
This course is a little bit disorganized.

I did not like this course at all. It overlapped with many of the courses that I've already taken. It didn't teach me anything new. The test questions were poorly written. The group assignments do not make sense. How do you expect 6 people to write one cohesive paper? The grading was also harsh. There should be exemptions for this course.
Worst class I have ever taken in my college career

-in a course with multiple professor and modules, the Canvas page is really important to be organized.  File naming conventions, folders that make sense, slides posted on time--none of that happened.  the Canvas page was disorganized and hard to navigate.
-assignments were tests.  No practice questions ever developed, no optional homework, no way to understand what each individual professor wanted us to take away--it was just good luck on the test.
-professors assumed we all had Bio and Epi backgrounds, and taught at a level that many people didn't understand (AMR)
-disjointed.  difficult structure for a such a huge class.  too many changes in the syllabus and kneejerk reactions that are not good in large core class.
-systems thinking, communication, leadership--I don't think those topics were well-practiced by the teaching team.
-Climate change professor was easy to follow, and I could find answers to his questions in the slides.  Prior knowledge and google worked better for AMR and obesity...
not that great

the leadership module adds very little to the course. there are a lot of minor assignments, and several times i forgot to turn them in. The number of assignments could be reduced, especially the leadership reflections, where I felt like the grading was arbitrary.
Good

I think that the design of the class was very interesting and could have been done well but due to the structure, it was not great. I liked how it talked about three topics but I think that it wasn't very cohesive because there were three professors teaching it with very different teaching styles. Moreover, there was no theme that tied all three subjects together so it seemed like we were doing work for three classes instead of one, especially with a cumulative final. I think this class could be improved by splitting the three sections and putting AMR into the intro epidemiology class and obesity into social justice and just keeping the class as climate change.

AP student
Climate change- I really enjoyed this section, the science behind it and how climate change affects health. Learned a lot in a short time.
AMR- Also loved this section, great overview and focused on the key public health elements'. The debate and negotiation were good
Obesity- Didn't enjoy this section as much, too much focus on individual level/biological aspects of obesity, when probably the greatest impact we will make as public health people are going to be the structural determinants and interventions eg soda tax, city planning, public transport
Leadership- Did not enjoy this, was very theoretical, repetitive assessments which I had to concoct answers for, didn't really learn anything from this or from health communications

I would add in some more of the class e-polls, sometimes became tedious waiting for a group to receive a microphone to answer a question then the answer they give is 'pass'...

This course, along with other large courses, should be online. The large auditorium is not conducive to learning. For some of us, the modules were repetitive since we have already taken a class about that specific module for an entire semester.

It was interesting to take a course that covered three separate topics in public health. The topics themselves were interesting, but the class was not structured in a way that was conducive to learning. The class was set up for mostly group work, but Harkness Auditorium was not the best place for this class, as it was difficult to sit with and discuss assignments with the groups.

This course was poorly designed. I felt like we brushed over these topics rather quickly and overall I practically learned nothing the way the course was structured. For the first assignment I don't know whose idea it was to have 6 people write one paper, but it wasn't a good one. Having to work in teams overall wasn't the problem but I think there should have been some sort of penalty system towards those in the groups who weren't contributing. The climate section had some parts that were just way too technical for an intro, and also I felt like the topics weren't really centered around public health. There should have been a much stronger presence of health overall. For the antimicrobial resistance module it was also very technical for an intro. I would say the same about the obesity module as well. I wish it focused more on diseases and overviews / big picture topics. The individual assignments were WAY too knit picky. They should have been testing us on broader themes and larger take aways. Overall, this course needs to be redesigned to cover larger view topics. It might have been better to break it up into three different classrooms and have us all rotate from one to the other after a few weeks so it's not such a large lecture and more personal / spark more discussion. I think it's important for us to be exposed to these topics, but it was not executed well at all. This is probably the only class that I have been completely disappointed about and would honestly like a refund towards my tuition for it.
THE WORST CLASS OF ALL TIME

This course needs some serious work for future YSPH students. I understand there are inherit challenges with teaching a new class, but I believe the multi-module format made it difficult to acclimated to a particular professor with his or her own teaching style. I strongly believe that the individual assignments were not indicative of a student's understanding of the material as well.

I thought that the group assignments/exercises in this class were at times a bit excessive and sometimes unnecessary. I would recommend a single final group project, as opposed to several small group assignments; it's hard/unnecessary to divide such small assignments among 5-7 people.
This course was frustratingly both incredibly dull and dumb and difficult as the assessments were deliberately tricky and did not pertain to course material.

I feel that this course requires some improvement. It teaches some really important and relevant topics in public health which were of interest to me. All of the lecturers were very knowledgable and taught well. However, I found the way that the course was structured, frustrating at times. We were often asked to do small group work and discussion during large lecture theater time which I just didn't find conducive to good participation or learning. The days where we broke into smaller groups to do group debates and negotiations were much more beneficial and enjoyable.

I really think that this type of course should NOT be taught in a giant lecture hall. I understand that its a requirement for all first-year students and a lecture hall is the best place to fit all of us at once, but I would have engaged much more with the material if the lecture size was smaller (if, for example, the YSPH class was split up into three classrooms). The material is important, but the format needs work.

Course structure was extremely poor. We are not guinea pigs for new courses and deserve better structured courses with positive learning environments. For instructors with so many years of experience, you would think they would know how to properly structure and execute a graduate level course. 
Overall this course was a mess. The instructors styles of teaching did not match. They went very granular on the topics without keeping in mind that some individuals did not even take any science subjects in college. The expectation to do group work in a loud lecture hall was ridiculous. It was so disorganized and did not create a positive learning environment. The group assignments were not helpful as well and the leadership component was tokenistic.
Excellent - but I think the course could be shorter.

Putting us into groups with leadership roles without providing separate rooms for discussion was not conductive to a learning environment. It was difficult finding where to sit with groupmates and hear them when discussing topics. Having group numbers picked out of a hat to speak in front the of the whole class was awkward, especially if you didn't have time to come to a conclusion for that question.  The multiple choice questions on canvas quizzes and exams were sometimes extremely vague and I did not feel like that were a clear answer provided.

I don't think this is an appropriate course for graduate students, especially the system thinking & leadership component. Totally unnecessary. 
The structure and workload of the first module is better than the other two.

This course needs another look. Tried to fit too much in at once. Three professors with varying teaching styles and ways of evaluating students was challenging. Group work was challenging. I appreciate how much must have gone into the logistic planning for this course but it was not great. Often hard to pay attention as content was dry and professors didnt even always seem like they wanted to be there. It felt like students did not respect this course and it made for a poor atmosphere all semester. I found the scope of content made it hard to be motivated in this course. Some content was so basic I found myself in need of a coloring book. Other content was so super specific, I found myself wondering if I would ever need to know it again. I wished the course focused a little more in the middle -- enough detail to understand critical issues - and more about what are we going to do about it. I wished for more discussion from professors about their ideas and solutions - or what has been tried and proven not successful. I found myself wondering so what often.  As I understand it, the fall curriculum was also mostly new, however those classes flowed much better. This course was a challenge.

I am very disappointed in this course. I love the concept of every public health professional being competent in major topics that transcend our departments.  However, the execution of the course was very poor. It felt sloppy and on-the-fly until the end. The fact that each module was organized so differently than the last, it made learning very difficult. Additionally, this lack of consistency made it difficult to learn because the teaching style change 3 times. Next year, each module should be organized exactly like the last. The professors need to agree on this. The individual "assignments" were midterms not so cleverly disguised. Timed and only available for a short period of time. It's an exam, not an assignment. 3 exams is annoying. I understand an exam for each module but still annoying. The "special topics" were a waste. Health communication and leadership are indeed skills and knowledge we need. But cramming this all into one course was a horrible idea. It was a disaster. These special topics can just be organized into mandatory Professional Skills Seminars that are offered during orientation so there is no class conflict and everyone can make it. They do not belong in this course. I felt like a genuinely learned during the climate change module. I came out of it feeling well primed to take an in-depth course on climate change. AMR wasn't overly informative because I'm in EMD. I'm not sure I learned anything during the Obesity module. The lectures were not organized well. The actual slides were barely legible and were just a cluster of random graphs and figures with barely any actual written content that I could learn from. I would also argue that addiction might be a better module than obesity. Especially considering New Haven itself having ongoing issues with substance use and the mass poisoning from last August.

Weaknesses:
-this class required a basic knowledge of biology which the professors decided to not explain whatsoever
-climate change individual assignment should have been on content to prepare us for the final
-Obesity slides were poorly organized and made it extremely difficult to study
-AMR required a very clear understanding of the course material to do well on the individual assignment but failed to provide enough time or material in lecture to allow us to understand this - instead this unit, like all of the others, was inundated with group work instead of substantive material that would have allowed us to study the course material in depth
-group assignments - they entirely detract from the content...expectations for the group assignments were POORLY articulated...in terms of sitting in a group - we are not elementary school students so please let us sit where we want to sit
-post the slides BEFORE CLASS so we can use them during lecture
-leadership reflections were a complete waste of time and this unit could have been incorporated during orientation week
-TFs were not appropriately equipped to answer questions about the course structure whatsoever because they, like everyone else, were left in the dark
-grading - what is the grading structure for group assignments?  And why are the averages so low for this mandatory class?
-this is probably the first time I have ever had every group member equally contribute and we were penalized continually for working together instead of having one person singlehandedly write a final product (as many groups did) 
-attendance: why isn't this rewarded?????? 

STRENGTHS:
-the course material that was intended to be taught was good but I, like many of my peers, walked away with maybe 5% of the understanding I was supposed to have gained

I am not trying to be overly dramatic but this was quite literally the dumbest class I have ever taken. It was completely frustrating and a waste of my time when we only have 2 years here. There was no flow to any of the modules, every teaching and assessment style was different, and having group work, individual assignments and a comprehensive final was completely over the top. I understand there are certain CEPH accreditation metrics that need to be met but shoving 15 of them into one course does no justice to any to them. I feel like  I wasted a lot of time and money taking this course and did not really learn anything that is applicable to what I want to do. Plus, now there really is no core environmental health class which is a disservice to that concentration. Leadership and systems thinking could be done in modules over 2 days like ethics (although ethics should really be something more)
Horrible execution of course aims.

I think the topics were really important as major health threats but I was hoping to learn deeper at the beginning of the semester. The group structure of the class was nice and helpful but it was almost impossible to do it in an auditorium. I liked the debate part especially, it was a very helpful experience. I have two major problems with the course. 
1. Changes!: The format of the exam changed, format of the assignments changed, due dates changed, the syllabus changed. And I really don't understand the reason of changing the format of an assignment since this was a new course. It was acceptable if they had bad experiences from the previous year (or at least from the first one) and change it but why are you doing this from the first assignment, and without any data? Where is the evidence-based approach that you focused all semester-long? I felt that we were not trusted.
2. I was really tired to get e-mails about this course! Almost everyday, we were receiving e-mails, at least one. After a certain point, I lost paying attention and was saying "ah, another e-mail from MHT" 
I really appreciate the enthusiasm of the all instructors who were experts in their field and I am thankful to them, the course just need to be improved and structured more effectively

Could have been organized differently
Overall, the 3 modules seemed to be joined for the sole purpose of graduation requirements
I liked the topics of the courses, however I think there should be a more efficient way to the group projects and discussions.

From the beginning it was clear that the convoluted structure (in content and administration) was designed for the sole purpose of satisfying new CEPH requirements. The pieces did not at all fit together well, which frustrated both the professors and students. This course had several weaknesses for which I would provide the following recommendations:
1. This course was VERY biology-heavy, which is unreasonable for a core course that is intended to reach a broad audience, most of whom do not have a biology background. This led to a high level of frustration among students. Future iterations of this course should be more accessible.
2. The assessments did not reflect what we "learned" in class. Much of the time, these tested synthesis and application of the material. However, many of the students did not have a strong enough background in the material itself to synthesize and apply it in the manner we were being tested. This led to very low grades and frustrated, angry students. In the future, individual assessments should more explicitly test lecture material itself. While this is a graduate level public health course, most of us do not have a strong background in biology. 
3. The grading for this class did not make much sense and was not communicated clearly. For group assignments, professors admitted their grading scale was "subjective" and when taking off points often only gave vague comments related to the prose of a group essay rather than the content provided. In many cases students received comments equating to "great content; essay structure needs work." This was particularly confusing given that students were under the impression they were being graded on their group collaboration and mastery of the information rather than their writing ability.
4. There was an unreasonable amount of work for this course. Students were so focused on accomplishing one task after another that they were not able to assimilate the material. This was a particular challenge because both the individual component and the group component appeared to be equally important. In the future, instructors should choose what will be the focus of the course-- either individual work or group work. 
5. The course structure (quick, modular, unrelated components) did not promote student understanding. Like the assessments, students learned how to get from one topic/assessment to the next and just manage one hurdle after another. In other words, students spent so much time and effort trying to understand the administrative side of the course that it made it difficult to retain content. 
6. Eliminate assigned seating in the lecture hall, and eliminate group cold calls. This only made the course more stressful for students. 

The only strength of this course was that it "checked the boxes." However, in doing so, it really was just trying to do too much.  

Overall, this course should be significantly restructured in future years, or eliminated altogether. If restructuring is an option, I would recommend breaking  up the components of this course and incorporating them into the existing MPH core classes or department-specific courses (i.e. HPM students focus on policy-related issues of these topics; CDE/EMD students focus on the epidemiology-related components of these topics).

Very disorganized, the goals of the course were not clearly set out or executed. Expectations were variable and the exams were not indicative of how much we knew about the topic. The exams were more about trying to trick the students with small details than to test knowledge. The exams almost felt like standardized testing, reading comprehension. The due dates for things were sporadic and sometimes the workload and how it was distributed was inconsiderate of the fact that most students are juggling many other courses and internships. The group activities as a whole were actually really effective and fulfilling, but the way the material was taught and the exams were absolutely useless.

Strengths - covers a broad range of important topics.
Weaknesses - the use of the group projects/group layout was not particularly effective, especially in Harkness (the physical space was not conducive to group learning). The group assignments often seemed slightly meaningless as well, seemed like they were just a lot of fluff/not much substance. 100-200 student lecture style is not usually great for student learning in general, and I think the lecture style of this course was particularly unfair to each of the instructors (Dubrow, Pettigrew, Yeckel). I am sure they would all be great instructors in a smaller classroom setting, but in such a large lecture it was difficult for both the students and the instructors.
an interesting course, but too much teamwork making us tired

Generally, the professors assumed students come in already having a basic knowledge of certain concepts although the course has no prerequisites, which is unfortunate and made it more difficult to learn. There were many times I felt like the "stupid" one in the room who was always playing catch-up. The professors also did not stick to their syllabus, and the changing number and type of assignments made it difficult to plan throughout the semester. Moreover, I think they try to teach/pack too many concepts into one class. Topics range from leadership to antimicrobial resistance to systems thinking. Perhaps, if they are all concepts we need to understand, some of the concepts may be embedded in other courses, so it it feels less like we are drinking water from a fire hose.

I thought the course had a lot of potential, and there was content that I loved.  The three content areas of the course - obesity, antimicrobial resistance, and climate change - are pressing issues that need to be addressed globally, and specifically in the field on public health. Providing three unique perspectives from respective experts in each field is a strength of this course. Similarly, I thought it was interesting to have a variety of different assignment types, including exams, essays, group assignments, and reflections.

However, there were also things I did not love about the course. This course felt rough around the edges and it was noticeable that the instructors were figuring things out as the course went along. They frequently changed their minds on due dates of assignments, on the structure of assignments, and what the primary takeaways were from each module. This was a disservice to the students. Grading at times felt arbitrary, and lacked objective guidelines - this was an admission of one of the instructors. He suggested there were no objective criteria for our first assignment, and as such he provided grades based on his gut feeling. Utilizing newer approaches to content delivery is great, although didactic expectations should come with objective criteria that students feel they are graded on equally. Uncoordinated efforts of the instructors undermined their intentions, and resulted in a lack of interest from many students. It was a source of frustration witnessing our cohort being used a testing-ground for this course.

Additionally, there was too much content provided for students to feasibly cover within a semester. It felt as if the instructors tried to pack as much content as possible into the course, without considering the impact and retention of students.

The material for all three modules is vitally important, but was not delivered in ways that were digestible. Simple lectures were followed by assessments that escalated in difficulty to levels that left a lot of my peers feeling discouraged and lost. The lack of organization overall made the course material hard to engage with. The idea is great, it just needs some tweaking.
N/a

Horrendous. They clearly gave ZERO thought to it. This course was meant to be about leadership, followership, teamwork and group collaboration. Then, they make the course 60% multiple choice, individual tests. As is that is relevant. The nitty-gritty questions are ridiculous when this course is for everyone and not those in one specialized area. I recall nothing from the course. They did not even give it any thought.

The whole structure with changing professors was a big weakness. Not having a consistent teacher was difficult because each of their teaching styles were very different. This in turn made exams harder to study for because we didn't know what to expect for each one. Additionally, the exams were poorly constructed and had little relation to the slides presented in class.

This course was not organized and not optimized for a good learning experience.   The lectures are always interrupted for discussion, and the discussions in the auditorium was not productive because we could barely hear one another over the 200 other people. The lectures also only touched on the surface of the problems, leaving much to our own discussion and therefore no one felt like they were actually learning anything useful. The leadership aspect was also unnecessary; everyone has had to work in groups before and there was no need for group people to work together for a whole semester.

This class was mostly a mess. While each instructor alone was fine, together, it was chaos. The structure of the course changed every three or so weeks and dates kept changing as well. It was unclear what we were supposed to get out of each portion of the class. The hands-on activities were helpful to a certain degree and I don't think I would have been able to make it through without a group, so definitely keep the group aspect. 

For next year, setting a very clear structure and following that structure from day one to week thirteen would be helpful. Also have all the professors teach with the same expectations. We had no idea what each instructor prioritized and it stressed everyone out.

This is a poorly designed course.  It was awkward to meet in 20-some groups of 6 in an auditorium. It was hard to discuss class topics with your group as some group members would essentially have to spin their heads like Reagan did in the Exorcist when she had the demon inside of her.  The alternative was sitting in a row of 6 without the head spinning issue.  However, when we tried that, we couldnt hear everyone.

The guest lectures were weak.  The PhD students were clearly interested in their research and well prepared, but a mostly disengaged auditorium was not the proper forum.

The leadership component felt forced and superficial.

This course should be taught as a small seminar.

This course was also thrown together without thinking about how it impacted other course offerings.  Those of us in the health policy track were literally unable to take required courses and had to scrounge around in the business school to find a Methods-like class.  That created domino effects in the scheduling process.

The group projects also suffered from some students taking on much more work than other students but not wanting to disclose this as some students were significantly better writers and researchers than other students.  Professors would not be aware of this because students dont want to jeopardize their relationships with other students, which are ultimately more valuable than equitably distributing work, and as a result dont disclose what is actually occurring with the group projects.  There is a lot of duplicity in the leadership self evaluations as students protect each other and dont disclose the reality of groupwork.

I appreciated the instructors, as well as the assignment of group work in conjunction with individual work. I think that as relevant and helpful as it is to learn about these threats to public health issues, people coming in with different levels of expertise on the matter in such a big class size led to the detriment of learning overall. I would've appreciated the three modules happening simultaneously--climate change, AMR, and obesity--but with three smaller sized cohorts taking each module. I still liked the group work which made the class size seem smaller than it what it actually was, but still, the larger class size led to diffusion of responsibility to answering questions in class. I think three smaller sized cohorts--similar to how some law school classes function--would be helpful.

This course was extremely disappointing. The "concept" was interesting, but the inability to pick groups we wanted to work with and the module set up was strange. There was incredible variation in the motivation between groups, and many people, like myself, were subsequently shafted with poor groups and poor grades. No matter how many "leadership" lectures there could have been, the fact that many students didn't take this course seriously resulted in poor outcomes for too many and I am furious that this sub-par course grade will be reflected on my transcript as a result of work my group members didn't feel compelled to put in.

This course was poorly organized and seemed very disjointed, with little overlap between the modules.  It was clear that these issues were thrown together in order to maintain CEPH accreditation rather than because of any overarching similarity or guiding principle. Many of our tests seemed to focus more on whether or not we understand foundational epi materials than on whether we understood core concepts in climate change, AMR, and obesity.  The best parts of this class were the debates and negotiations, where we were able to take our understanding of these issues and apply them to relevant applications.

This class was terrible. A mess of a course. While in theory and I'm sure in intention, this class would have been amazing - a survey class learning about major health threats, in practice the class was disjointed and unorganized. This class was certainly not a survey course - many of us lacked the foundation education in climate/environmental studies, biology, CDE/EMD, to appreciate the new course material (control + F, being the saving grace for many). 

This class needs an incredible overhaul. The professors should try to align their teaching styles and evaluation styles (each exam was different and difficult to maneuver), we do not need 10 assignments over the course of the semester; group work in the auditorium is the epitome of messy. 

I would have loved a survey class that actually went over the main concepts of current major health threats - but this was an epi class, disguised as a core class, with ceph accreditation standards forced into it.

Worst course I have ever taken in my entire life. Learned absolutely nothing. Professors were incapable of teaching an iota of information. If Yale has any sense of decency it will refund the student's who took this course the $4000 it was worth. To think that you can turn a 150+ lecture class into a "groups" type course is beyond asinine.

I understand the purpose of this course, but it was one of the worst classes I have ever taken. Its structure was very confusing and the assessment process did not seem to be an efficient way to accomplish the goals of this course. The individual assessments very detail oriented and seemed to be better suited for a class that was solely focused on each of the units. It was extremely frustrating to struggle with these assessments despite preparing for each one as if it was a closed-note exam (they were open-note through Canvas).  For instance, the final exam consisted of 39 questions, and a substantial portion of those questions felt like riddles in their phrasing. Again, I must emphasize how frustrating it is to prepare for an exam, even though it is open-note, only to be deterred by the phrasing of the questions. For a course that emphasizes group work and development of leadership skills, requiring such technical individual exams seems counterproductive. It would have made more sense to focus solely on group projects for each module. I truly hope that next year's cohort has a better experience with this course.

Very important themes and generally interesting. First year of the course so understandable that it was a mixed bag. Prof Dubrow seems nice but could do with a shot of enthusiasm when delivering lectures to engage the audience. Some of the detail seemed way too granular for general MPH candidates, unless you're an EMD student, particularly with regard to AMR and HIV treatment. Group activities were decent enough, lots of class discussion which was difficult in the lecture setting in Harkness.
The course was interesting and covered important topics, but might benefit from a more clear structure.

OVERALL Strength: highlights 3 key major health threats; appreciated that the individual assignments were take-home; however, indirect sources report a significant amount of group work for these assignments... perhaps mixing up questions a bit more would have been good.
Leadership: quite rudimentary discussion; could have been done as a module with actual class exercises practicing these principles during those 2-3 lectures

Climate change: provided a foundational introduction to climate change where I didn't have prior understanding; lecture style was quite dry, however, and individual assignment seemed more like an epidemiological exercise, rather than an exercise investigating climate change

AMR: most engaging lecturer of the 3; enjoyed the debate leading into a final group paper

Obesity: highly relevant topic, but seemed to overemphasize biological principles instead of foundational public health measures (school food options, housing structure); practical application and interventions would have seemed more worthwhile

The topics they chose were awful. For example, obesity truly is a serious health threat to the US citizen, but it is not a problem in many countries like Japan and China. Please think about international students when designing the course!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This was the worst course I have taken in my academic career. It was very frustrating to be in this class because I felt like it was a waste of time and I didn't like the feeling that this was an experiment gone awry. I am also taking courses at the School of Management and I have never felt like they were wasting my time, while I frequently feel like that at YSPH. I think the climate change module was significantly worse than the other two modules. I do not think that Robert Dubrow is a good lecturer, or, to give him the benefit of the doubt, not good in a large lecture setting. The attempts to get audience feedback during his lectures were painful, and I was frequently the only one participating. I'm really disappointed because I think that climate change is THE issue of my generation but there was no enthusiasm or urgency communicated. The anti-microbial resistance section was ok. Again, I was missing the enthusiasm and the urgency. I think the obesity module could have been good but I was so over it by that point.

In terms of the assignments and the evaluations, I did not appreciate the reading-comprehension feel of the canvas assignments. There was little to no critical thinking required, I just ctrl f'ed my notes. The other assignments were better, but I did not feel particularly challenged. This was not what I was expecting of grad school, I was not challenged by this class.

I am much more interested in thinking about the ways in which policies can attempt to mitigate these issues. I thought that is what we were going to do, but I feel like this course fell short.

I hated writing papers as a group.

I would like to suggest that this course be split into 3 sections, maybe by departmental groups, so that the sections are smaller, and have the three professors rotate through. If it were by departmental groups, the policy people could focus on policy solutions and the epi people could focus on that. I think it would be more interesting and people could more easily participate in the smaller class sections

I respect all the work of instructors and TFs. But, this course is really a disaster for me. This class has a lot of questions about biology, which makes no sense for a policy student. It is not fair for us to take the quiz in which all the questions are about biology. The course design assumes we have a background in biology, which is not true. It makes us feel frustrated and not interested in the classes. I am not saying that we don't need to learn these things. What I mean is if this course is required for all students from the background, it should teach us more about biology first. I understand the time is limited but the course design definitely should be improved. It is really not fair for policy student without any biology background to take the exams of anti-biotics and obesity.

Strengths - important concepts to be discussed as part of Core MPH, attempted leadership/teamwork aspects of the class were well-intended
Weaknesses - poor structure, timing, and delivery of information. Way too much detail about each module and expected to understand and apply too much information on complex topics after a short amount of time. Teamwork in class was unsuccessful when group members had no incentive to show up.

Very smart and accomplished instructors... BUT the TF's were very incompetent and vague with their expectations.
This course felt like a waste of tuition and too experimental. As someone paying full tuition for an education I was disappointed.
The strength were the material presented but it was done in a very disorganized manner.

While this course provided interesting content, I felt that the course went too in-depth for what was supposed to be a survey of climate change, antimicrobial resistance, and obesity. For example, the obesity unit focused a lot on the physiology of obesity. For a public health course, shouldn't we also be thinking about policy, behavior change, systemic factors that shape obesity, etc.? In contrast, I felt that the climate change module effectively provided a survey of climate change and health, with an appropriate balance of climate change science and links between climate change and health. 

I also felt that the individual assignments did not fairly assess what we learned in class; again, they just felt way too high level for a 4-week session. I wonder if a future version of this class could focus on just one of the major health threats. In that case, we could explore the problem all of its levels: individual physiology through systemic factors.  Otherwise, I very much enjoyed the group work and felt that the number and content of group assignments allowed group members' diverse perspectives to shine through.

I think that the idea behind this course was good but to was poorly executed. When so many instructors are involved it is hard to learn the style of each one and learn effectively. I also think that having the whole course formatted in groups was frustrating. I also felt that often we would be expected to achieve unrealistic turnaround times on assignments, especially taking into consideration the extra time needed to coordinate in a group.
Messy

Three different modules (+ systems thinking and leadership) in one course are a good idea in theory, but it was a sloppy course and I don't feel like I learned much about any of the topics because they were either too introductory (climate change + obesity) or way over my head (AMR). All course modules should be taught at the same level (introductory, but to an audience that has heard about them/may have some familiarity). Some method of assessment of students' familiarity could be implemented at the beginning to assess the level to teach at/provide students supplementary basic materials at the beginning of modules?

This course was poorly designed and run. There were not any rubrics for the group projects.
The lectures felt disjointed and like cramming 2 years of PhD level material into less than a 1/3 of a semester. It was clear the the professors were knowledgeable, but it was also clear that they were not meeting the majority of students where they were. 
The was also unclear objectives for each lecture, so we were unsure of exactly what we should be expected to know.
Furthermore, the topics were not easily bridged in lecture or by assignment.

This was, by far, the worst course I have ever taken. The leadership, communication, and systems thinking components did not effectively teach any of these skills in a practical or applied way. I never did any of the readings and still did well in the course. The group structure was meant to encourage interdisciplinary teamwork, but we could not effectively work in groups because it was so loud in the lecture hall. Smaller classrooms or a room where group members could face each other would be nice. The TFs did not engage with the groups much. The leadership evaluations were not rigorous and quite tedious. They did not prompt genuine reflection on team dynamics or leadership/followership. The instructors did not indicate any interest in supporting students and accepting these criticisms. The instructors did a poor job of connecting the three topics and ensuring that their evaluations reflected the depth of the material covered in the course. The take home tests did not encourage deep learning. I am deeply disappointed with this course and the faculty and administrators involved. I believe this could have been a much more positive learning experience had the instructors and TFs been sensitive and responsive to these issues throughout the course.

I did like how the class revolved around group work. I liked my group how we collaborated together. However there were weaknesses in the structure of the class. There were times some things were confusing and I didn't like how the modules were lined up. We should have been given options on what modules we wanted to do. Also I thought course was very epi based. It was a bit unfair to those students who weren't epi focused as they could find the quizzes quite difficult. The quizzes should have been more generic and grasp the module overall rather than being so epi focused.

I don't think the course was structured in a way that was conducive to teaching what the syllabus stated. The leadership and teamwork components of the course seemed like they were haphazardly integrated. Additionally, we were encouraged to work in teams but were not always compensated for our work (i.e. the MORDOR study debate during the AMR module) and were instead given individual assessments which were not always reflective of the content taught.

This course needs to be reformed. While I like the team-based structure, the material needs to be woven together better. As well, the testing style needs to be more content or application-based. I feel as if most of what we learned in class was not tested. It was taught at either too basic or too high of a level with respect to the diverse backgrounds of people in the room. By taking two mini climate change quizzes rather than a reading-based climate quiz, it would better prepare students for the final and make sure that they are learning the material. With respect to AMR, it needs to be more basic science. Many students felt lost and like they could not succeed because of the higher-level science. Obesity was focused on individual factors, when a lot of obesity is due to structural level, systematic factors impacting individuals. The debate, negotiations, and project proposals were the highlights of this course. One could add something similar in the climate change section; for example, students could have a budget and need to make NYC more climate friendly by investing in mitigation/adaptation measures.

I greatly appreciated the opportunity to collaborate with fellow classmates in this course, and thought the papers on various topics were great. That is where I, and many of my fellow students felt they had the opportunity to really share their knowledge and excel. However, writing such short papers with six group members was really ridiculous. This class would be better served if longer papers were the only form of assessment, instead of quizzes that asked oddly specific questions unrelated to the main knowledge presented in class. Having multiple instructors presenting different topics was an interesting concept, but poorly executed. There were no (natural or otherwise) transitions between material, and it very much felt that we were being taught a class in the conceptual stage, which was nowhere near ready to be taught to MPH students. Having constant small group interaction in a massive lecture hall was a huge mistake. It made learning extremely difficult, particularly when I could not hear my group mates most of the time over the din of the other students in the lecture hall. The idea to call on groups in this massive lecture hall was also great in theory but extremely impractical and a huge impediment to learning in this class. I'm disappointed that I learned next to nothing, and I feel that I wasted my time and efforts for a grade that did not reflect my knowledge of the materials taught.

The course lacked coherence. The climate change module was fantastic-- readings were relevant, and the lectures were concise and organized, but I had a hard time following the AMR and Obesity modules. More work needs to be put into the lectures so that they fit the audience; ironically, this was a topic that the course was supposed to teach.
Too challenging, too hard to learn, too much information
Room choice could have been better which would have encouraged some more participation.

this class was poorly structured. the topics were simply too large to cover in module style. for students who did not have a baseline in the respective topics, it was difficult to keep up with the material in a manageable and meaningful way.

This course is the WORST one I've ever had at YSPH. I think the topics are important, but the way it is being taught is so bad. The class requires much background in biology, which to be honest, many of us don't have. And the tedious reflections basically cannot represent any of my learnings in the class, but I have to make up stuff in order to earn the points.

This whole class was an awful experience. From the auditorium setting, to the group discussions, individual and group projects. The only strength of this entire class was the wonderful TFs who got our groups through it! Brooke Severe was the most wonderful individual and helpful when we really thought no one could help us in this process.
Again it may be the size of the auditorium that makes it difficult to engage with the class. It would be interesting to try more smaller classroom discussions into this class.

Poor.  All three course instructors have their own weaknesses.  Dr Dubrow covered way too many materials and had too much assigned reading plus videos.  Not at all realistic plus his constant Canvas posts and corrections irritated most of the class--it even prompted the TFs to write instructions on how to turn off Canvas announcements on mobile devices--IT WAS THAT BAD.  

Dr Pettigrew was probably the best among the three of them.  But she assigned too many last minute work.  Geez, give us at least 2 weeks to work on something big such as writing an entire group paper.  Her quiz also asked way too many specific Biology questions that was beneficial to arguably the CDE students in the course given their course work with her in PID.  

Finally, the worst of the three:  Dr Yeckel.  You are the course leader--put some structure to the course!   Nice lady and I hear she is a great mentor.  But she is the primary culprit in making this course the worst course at YSPH given her lack of structure and initiative.   I am normally a proponent of giving people 2nd chances.  But please, do not let her teach an important class ever again.

There was no organization whatsoever and no cohesion within modules or overall amongst instructors. Professor Pettigrew's section especially was extremely granular and felt like taking an undergrad biology class. The module assessments/quizzes were a waste of time. It would make better sense to have the final for the class be a paper looking at overall themes in climate change, AMR, and obesity.

very chaotic. not very organized. keep receiving messages about the class every day and it seems the instructors change mind frequently. doesn't seem to have a good align of the three modules plus the leadership module. not very clear about the purpose of the class. I learnt things here and there but none of them is in depth or systematic. i don't understand why we should do the leadership evaluation for each module....feels like i am an elementary school student. All MPH students are forced to take the class and forced to build teams with random people. this course is a good example of bad leadership.

this course was extremely disorganized and illogical, and reminded me how our class is a guinea pig sample for ill-designed courses that made no sense. 
 It seemed as if the course was a by-product of overly-ambitious, and insular, top-down brainstorming.

 i understand the importance of the climate and obesity/chronic disease as modules, but AMR is currently such a niche public health topic that assumes so much scientific/biology knowledge that was not expected (as well as the test questions about it).  also the climate module was overly-scientific and expected competency on material for quizzes that were not addressed in class (this was the case with the AMR module).  

instead - maybe health communication, systems thinking, and leadership can replace it as a module -- since so much attention is paid to it with 4 lectures in total paid to --which is only 2 or so lectures difference from the AMR module

Strength: students can learn 3 major health treat topics in one class, good collaboration with classmates
Weakness: fragmented classes, instructions for certain work may be not clear, demanding workload, rely heavily on assigned group mates.

Strengths: Built patience and survivor skills 
Weaknesses: Is everything too harsh of an answer? Okay not everything Harkness is a great auditorium for lectures so long as you aren't required to work in groups..... wait
Bad
too crowded classroom and noisy

The topics in this course could have been covered as a mandatory seminar. They could have been covered in webinar modules.
