The course could have been split into a Monday and Wednesday section and a Tuesday and Thursday section and we could have instead been in a more reasonably sized room like Winslow. The topics could have been cut down to just cover 1 or 2 specific case studies each. The individual assessments could have been more problem-solving based and less memorization. The group work could have been one single project. There could have been a structured section aside from lecture instead of this "optional" after lecture time students were not going to want to participate in, especially those who commute to campus or have children to pick-up or who have to work almost full-time just to afford this program. The optional group time could have been slotted for before lecture.
Too much class time dedicated to contents that students can learn themselves. Group activities can be more meaningful if students have projects to make impact.

I found the course was a waste of resources. As an EMD student, I was already educated on antimicrobial resistance by the instructor, and would have preferred taking two separate classes in EHS and CDE and seminars on leadership and communication as opposed to short bursts of material that were out of my depth. I didn't understand why I was paying for another class to learn the exact same thing nor why I was taking a class that was designed not to give me a comprehensive education on the topic. All of us are intelligent and driven, and yet all of us struggled with the material and with engagement in the class. We are educated and concerned about climate change and obesity as epidemics, yet this class did not play on that. The instructors, bar Dr. Pettigrew, dove into complex mechanisms that most of us had no foundation for, and tested us on questions that were more epidemiological in nature than representative of what we have learned..

Strengths: Having students work in an interdisciplinary manner, where their different expertise and departmental knowledge helps tackle problems. 
Weaknesses: Group discussion and collaboration in Harkness Auditorium was unruly; short-notice about assignments; lack of accountability within student groups; no apparent thread or theme across the modules.

The strengths of this course were initially its weakness, but I think that this was because students were not quite yet used to working in teams yet. This ended up being a great strength of the course, as we all learned how to work in teams to complete papers, present solutions to longstanding issues in public health, and provide insight to others. This was not the easiest process, but in retrospect, this was probably an essential skill to master in grad school!
Very kind, approachable and responsive to students. Sometimes the teaching was a bit scattered and confusing, but overall she was very enthusiastic and engaging.
Very nice instructor but unfortunate that this course was such a drag.
strength: explain everything clearly, communicate with students in the class.
Professor Yeckel is a great lecturer and really tried to get make a big lecture feel smaller with break out activities.
Lacked communication on deadlines and about course expectations
very friendly and approachable

Catherine was wonderful in the face of a poorly designed course. Her module was incredibly engaging; she structured group work the best of all professors teaching this course by having us draft the bulk of the work during a "hackathon"-esque class.

I found her lectures non linear, her slides difficult to read and follow when looking back, and the flow of information difficult to follow. As a physician I found her difficult to follow with her examples (graphs that were not introduced, asking "guess what I'm thinking" instead of open ended questions, not asking people to interpret the basic graph before moving to the deeper meaning). It seemed like she assumed some knowledge of physiology of which I'm not sure how much most MPH students have. She seemed to get so excited about the end/final points of her slides that she often overlooked and under explained how she got there.

Dr. Yeckel is an excellent professor. She is engaging and very approachable. It is clear from her teaching style that she is genuinely interested in the material and also in the success of her students. I enjoyed learning from here.

She is nice. But the material was repetitive and the examination of her specific module (obesity) had many failures.
Canvas exam had many typos and was really hard to read. It was also designed poorly, with empty answers. All this made the exam extremely confusing.
In my opinion, the exam did not reflect the things that were taught in class.

I like her, she sparks interesting discussions and is clearly an expert on what she teaches. However, I think her lectures could be improved; I had trouble following sometimes and staying engaged with the material. I think a little bit more organization would improve the lectures tremendously.

Overall clearly very kind, smart, and passionate about the topic.

The execution of the class was bumpy and rough.

For the first module, there was a lot of reading directly off the slides. I know that Professor Dubrow is a brilliant man so I would have loved to have learned more from him personally that I wasn't necessarily just reading off of a slide or hearing in a video.
Devoted,!very hard working. Engaged very much. I do appreciate for her efforts in the course. She organized the course very hard, and she is also very nice to offer help.

Very passionate professor. I really enjoyed her enthusiasm, although I really didn't enjoy the structure or content covered in the class. Her assignments were somewhat boring/easy and felt like busy work. I would have liked the option to take a deeper dive into the material. I did like the professors individually and would like to take a course with them in the future (as independent, stand-alone courses).

Dr. Yeckel is a nice person but her slides and exam questions for module 3 were poorly designed and often contained grammatical errors.
However, she is very responsive over email and willing to help the students.

Clearly very knowledgable about the public health challenges associated with obesity; however, this professor is not particularly engaging in lecture and tends to bounce around from topic to topic distractingly and ineffectually.

Professor Yeckel lost her credibility in the health communication lecture when she used stigmatizing language when talking about obesity* and called a woman in a photo "exotic." Her exam was written in a stream of consciousness and often did not make any sense. I had a very hard time taking her and her module seriously.

*There was a public health advertisement that she presented that essentially blamed people for getting chronic diseases because they eat cake.

Professor Yeckel was a fine lecturer, did not seem to focus on the interesting/ policy solutions around obesity. Also, her quiz desparately needed to be proofread, was full of mistakes and confusingly worded questions.
Professor Dubrow is a gem of a human, slides were fine but really missed an opportunity to talk about policy. If we're not talking about solutions, why even learn about this issue?
Professor Pettigrew was a very good lecturer but seemed to have absolutely no understanding of what our biology background is, and I don't understand why the quiz was asking about such minute details of bacteria selection. Is this really necessary? Is this what you want the takeaway for all 200 of us to be? 

Very frustrated by the seemingly disjointed lectures from all 3 that lacked "big picture takeaways."
Compared to Dr. Pettigrew and Dr. Dubrow, Dr. Yeckel was good. The other two were not engaging, did not explain materials well, or had productive courses.
not sure if the course was relevant to my interests
All over the place and didn't answer our questions.
Eh. Was not her biggest fan. Way too all over the place.
Fine person.

Prof. Yeckel is very kind and passionate about her topic. It was clear that she tried her best to engage students in the class and wanted us all to do well. However, he slides are hard to read and her notes were incoherent. I could not follow her lectures despite forcing myself to pay attention and taking rigorous notes. Despite all that, I could not use any of the class material - her slides and my notes - to study for the class or do the individual assignment because the information was so poorly presented. Also, her questions were extremely tricky and poorly worded; there were a lot of typing errors and sentences that made little sense, and the questions were too technical for someone without a deep biology background.
Appreciate the passion for the subjects.   Overall disjointed, and hard to follow, and hard to know expectations.  Didn't convey priorities well.
Very kind
She is a great professor, and listens to her students when they have concerns.
Great teacher

I think that all of the professors were decent but together, it felt very forced putting these professors and topics together. It was hard to learn and study for the class when all the topics were so different and all the professors' approaches were different. I think that if the professors worked together more to make a cohesive theme, it could be improved.

Strengths: Answers questions, approachable, cares about students
Weaknesses: The key learning concepts in obesity classes weren't always easy to pick out which reflected in my marks for the obesity assessments.

This is a new course though so I'm sure there will be some learnings to be taken from the first iteration.
She tried, but this course was dead before it began.
Each faculty member brought a number of key strengths to his or her own module of expertise.

She is very passionate about the subject and wants the course to be successful. I really appreciate this and I think she has really listened to the recommendations that many people have given and will make some changes in the future that will really improve the course.
Great! Very approachable and passionate about teaching the course and her own work.

She failed to provide a positive learning environment. Having so many instructors was chaotic and not helpful. I can see that she is passionate about this and teaching but whoever designed this course missed the target which resulted in poor execution.
Excellent.

provide better forms of assessment of what students have learned from the class. A better transition between topics could also have been used. The syllabus was changed multiple times and we never really knew what to expect from the class or when exams/projects were going to due as it always seems to be changing.

Probably best of the three. At least she seemed to want to be there. The group work for the obesity section built on itself and was thus, more manageable. Also seemed more applicable in a professional setting.

All professors were generally nice.  But for this course: Failed to provide any background of biology that would have allowed us to understand the modules.  Slides were poorly organized and provided literal clarity to the students (or TFs for that matter).  There were continual complaints and feedback given during this semester and all professors failed to take that into consideration.

Catherine was fine and clearly cared about the course but she was the only instructor to be at class every session. Rob and Melinda peaced out as soon as their modules were done and clearly didn't really care about how it went for the rest of us. Her assessments were very abstract which was difficult in a course structured like this because you had no opportunity to learn how to take her tests or what kind of questions she asks.
Instructors were not engaging.
I liked Dr. Yeckel and her enthusiasm

The instructors were trying to do too much with this course and it appeared as though they were just as frustrated as the students. In addition, it was clear that the professors had different priorities. For instance, some focused on engaging students with the material while others were more concerned with presenting the material only. In addition, the vast differences in assessments and grading styles showed that they were not on the same page. 

There should be more continuity in teaching styles if this course continues to be taught in its modular format.
All three professors are very knowledgeable and passionate about each of their subjects.
Great

With three instructors for this course, there were strengths and weaknesses of each. Overall, I felt that Melinda Pettigrew and Catherine Yeckel were more engaging as instructors.

Robert Dubrow is very knowledgeable about the impacts of climate change on health and the many concerns we should address. As a lecturer, he is not engaging and needs to work on content delivery. During the climate change module, it was evident at times that few students were paying attention to his lecture. Catherine Yeckel was engaging, passionate, and interesting as a lecturer. I feel her expectations for students were the most well understood.

Further, the first two instructors (Dubrow & Pettigrew) were very slow at providing students with feedback on their assignments. For example, despite the large size of the course, students were divided into groups (32 in total). Dubrow took 5 weeks to grade 32 papers. This is unacceptable, given that this duration is nearly half the semester, and we had moved into a new content area.
Dr. Yeckel is amazing and was the glue that held this whole ship together. She and her peers, though, need to create a course with more cohesion and flow.
N/a
n/a
The module lectures were typically beyond the scope of half the class, and no matter the instruction, it proved to be a completely ineffective way to bridge gaps between disciplines.
I enjoyed the Obesity Module and felt that I learned a lot. However, the individual assessment for this module felt the most confusing (compared to the previous module) in terms of question phrasing.
Generally interesting and good lecturer. Very interested in and receptive to feedback.
Dr. Yeckel was very kind and supportive throughout the semester. Extremely knowledgeable and provided insightful feedback.
They're knowledgeable and considerate.
Definitely the best of out the three lecturers, her module felt the most well thought out. obviously all topics are relevant but i feel like this one was presented in a better way.
Dr. Yeckel was engaging and I have no complaints.
Dr. Yeckel definitely brings energy to the classroom. I enjoyed her instruction style (a mixture of lectures and in-class group work).

She was enthusiastic about her topic, but I felt she taught at too introductory a level for the module to be worthwhile. The slow pace of the class and material also left me feeling disengaged and restless. Obesity is an interesting topic and I preferred her method of turning in pieces of our project over time to one big final assignment.
Dr. yeckel is clearly very smart, but her lectures were difficult to follow and she glossed over nuanced pieces she tested us on. The powerpoints also felt in complete got review and for note-taking

I thought Dr. Yeckel did a good job teaching with the course. She was very helpful and did a good job filling me in on assignments I had a missed. I never had any trouble communicating with her throughout the course. One thing I was not a huge fan of was how the course was taught by three different professors. I really wish it was just taught by one professors as sometimes I thought the material was rushed and it was hard to transition between modules.
I'm not sure what the point of only evaluating this professor is when she taught maybe a quarter of the class?

Dr. Yeckel is clearly passionate about the class, and I think she put forward a sincere effort to make things go smoothly. However, I think she could benefit from a speaking coach, because she often would start a sentence and never finish it. I know that other students who do not speak English as a first language struggled with her lectures because Dr. Yeckel would start to make a point and never finish it.
Understand students' feeling

I dont know what to say about Ms. Yeckel. I think the evaluation should be inclusive of all four of our instructors in this class not just one. This was an awful experience trying to learn difficult skills and material in a matter of weeks without the proper background or knowledge. Each professor taught, tested, and graded differently and not just myself but most of us constantly felt defeated no matter how much effort was put in.

Improvements: pick one method: group project or individual. Dont mix the two. Dont teach in an auditorium if you want group discussions. Have a streamlined curriculum not four different in the span of a semester. Actually use peoples notes and complaints provided by the TFs throughout the semester to make improvements. Add a grading section for attendance.

None.  Her poor leadership and management skills as a course leader are so severe, I feel it is unsalvageable at this point.  Also, talk about the way she words her quiz/exam questions.  



The convoluted way she asks questions in her quizzes and exams is a bastardization of the English language.  It is also unfair to the international students in the course to be subjected to the cacophonous barrage of word salad and linguistic dissonance in our formal assessments.
I appreciate Dr. Yeckel's enthusiasm throughout the class and how engaged she is with students. She was supportive of our ideas and challenged us to think outside the box.

She is very passionate, but I don't find her engaging as an instructor. To be fair, I think this class did her and the other instructors a disservice bases on how it was organized. All the professors are very qualified but were forced to teach in a restricted and remedial way to an audience of apathetic students.
good instructor just the structure of the course should be improved.
Great!
strength: very friendly and helpful

Which Instructor? There were 3 maybe 4? and 4 different topics... in one class... yiiiikkkkkeeeeessssssssssss. All the instructors were of course brilliant.. Brilliant at brushing over in-depth topics in class and then hammering home insane specifics on take home exams. The stark contrast between the lecture material and exam questions was only exasperated by the revolving door of teaching styles, content, and assignments. Overall this created a confusing, chaotic, and very frustrating course.
Very kind.
professor with passion and caring
None of the professors felt reasonably accessible.
Very helpful and knowledgeable about the subject

I found both her and the class to be scattered and at times, random. I understand she had to do her best with the new requirements but this class was sloppily patched together. The module on obesity was easily the hardest and most incoherent, and also found to be outdated and body negative in its ideals, as it is widely accepted in the medical community that BMI is not the best measure for obesity anymore.

The instructors for each of the modules generally need to reconfigure class material and lectures to acknowledge that many students may not have a strong scientific background and understanding of the topics being addressed. As such, instructors could spend more time explaining the basics or fundamentals in their respective modules before launching into the intricacies.
All of the professor for this course were phenomenal, and outstandingly knowledgable in their respective spheres.

ABSOLUTELY WOULD NOT RECOMMEND. Awful, awful course. Poorly conducted, not interesting or stimulating....only needed for MPH accreditation. Worst class I have ever taken IN MY ENTIRE LIFE. Shame on YSPH for thinking this was a good way to conduct a graduate-level course. I'm so glad this course is over and I can never revisit this experience again.
This course is helpful for building general knowledge on major health threats.
A hot mess that should be a seminar not a course.

Unfortunately, I would not recommend this course to other students as I am highly dissatisfied. Lack of organization and inability to follow expectations set forth in a syllabus is unacceptable. Additionally, I gained no real skillset as the assessments seemed highly variable and did not reflect the content that was focused on in lecture. Group work, while absolutely an important skill, was largely distracting in this class. Short papers aren't necessarily conducive for group work in large teams.
I would not recommend this course! It is really random, expected a lot, and I don't think I learned anything from it.
variety of topics, important ones, but a large crowd (sometimes unmanagable)

This class was a mess. Unfortunately you'll probably be required to take it due to accreditation requirements, and hopefully with critique/commentary from students this year they will restructure both the content and syllabus. Good luck if you have to take it...and if you don't, don't.

This course had a lot of moving parts and a lot of busywork along with it. The group work was somewhat contrived and could be significantly improved. Overall the antimicrobial resistance and climate change in health modules were very informative and stimulating.

No. I know it's a core and is required. But it was a mess. One group assignment a semester is enough, but we had three group and three individual assessments. That is more than I have had in any other grad class. I had issues with the parameters. The discontinuity between the modules. And not having any idea what to expect on the final. Assessments were not reflective of the lectures. Feedback on the first module was not helpful. Felt like I was a child being taught about leadership and graphic organizers. I know some of these things are necessary for accreditation, but there's a way to do it that doesn't make your students feel like you're trying to hold our hands and teach us something that we've been doing since elementary school.

I envision this course will be much better next year after some of its first year challenges are smoothed out. It's a mandatory class, but it's clear to see why. You learn fundamental skills relevant to public health and teamwork.

I could not recommend this course to a fellow student. Compared to every other required first-year, all-class courses I took this was the worst in terms of organization and accessibility. I haven't taken a math class since 2009 and still found Biostatistics to be more accessible than this course, which theoretically should have given all students from every concentration an interesting view into pressing concerns in the public health world today. Instead, the topics got bogged down in details that were too complex and lacked relevance (such as horizontal gene transfer or outmoded teaching regarding how one's race supposedly maps onto BMI) for many students, including myself. 

I think that the intentions of this class are good and it could have been very illuminating but completely missed the mark. Too little consideration went into the development of course material to ensure that all students would be able to access material, even if some may have found it a bit easier than others. I would highly suggest, should this course be offered again, that professors for this course meet with those that teach Intro to Epi and Intro to Biostats-- both of which considered that students would enter the course with varying backgrounds but established a solid foundation to build up from during the semester.
Poorly designed. Poorly delivered. Need to change many things.

This course covers three main modules: climate change, antimicrobial resistance, and obesity. Additionally, leadership and system thinking are incorporated into the class. 

I would personally not recommend this class, although the class is required so my opinion doesn't matter that much. I am hoping that the class will improve based on this year's feedback; the first year of a huge course is bound to be rough along the edges. It has a lot of potential and could be really great if some changes are made. However, this year it was very unorganized and inconsistent. Group work was very difficult in the Harkness Auditorium.

Definitely would not recommend this class. Hopefully some major changes are made -- maybe if I had learned about more policy information, the class would've been more tolerable. I felt like I was taking an upper-level epidemiology class, which I was not at all prepared for.

This course covers three major health threats (climate change, AMR, and obesity) along with several special topics. I would not recommend the class under the current model. In trying to manage many different concepts at once and keep up with the working parts of the course, I didn't engage with the material as deeply as I would have hoped.

I'd summarize it like a requirement that you must do to get your degree, but that the only part you'll look forward to is seeing some of your friends in class and commiserate about how unclear the breakout sessions are, how disjointed trying to cram 4 separate topics in one class is, and how thankful you are that it's almost over. I'd highly highly recommend that administration re-think the delivery of this class, this format did not work. 

I hate to say this, but probably my single most unfavorable class experience at YSPH.
I would not recommend it in its current form but I think that it has a lot of potential for the future if changes are made!
A course of some issues related to public health. Not for non-biology students. May not recommend for biostatistics students.

Overview of obesity, climate change, and anti-microbial resistance (major health threats) to public health work. Kind of a waste of time. I would not recommend. The assignments weren't interesting (although I did appreciate the Climate Change and Obesity modules separately and would have preferred to see them/take them as independent courses) and the group projects were boring. It is a required course.

This course is a core requirement unfortunately so MPH candidates have to take it. I would definitely not recommend it because of its poor design and inability to foster a positive learning environment.

This is a newly developed and required course for M.P.H. students, so you'll need to take it eventually. It's not particularly difficult content-wise or work-wise, but group work can be frustrating, particularly if attendance remains optional.
This course is unfortunately required, so my recommendation does not matter. I truly hope that serious changes take place so that next year's students do not have to go through this experience.
Would not recommend but unfortunately you have to take it so all I can say is : good luck.
Do not take this course. It was one of the worst courses I have ever taken
Nope, but you'll have to take it anyway :).
Unfortunately, it is required; otherwise, I would not recommend it at all.
so bio heavy!
This course is an actual course the same way I am a professional basketball player, or YSPH a respectable school.
All over the place. Tests did not reflect what we were learning that well and too much emphasis on group work when group members didn't show up.
A course I wouldn't wish upon my own worst enemy. Hopefully this course undergoes a massive overhaul. It is just a shame that YSPH have this sort of introduction.
I would highly NOT recommend this class.
Again, garbage course. 0/10
The content is well organized and the professors trying to convey us the sense of leadership in public health. But I do not strongly recommend it to fellow students.

It is an important course, but it did not live up to its potential. These health threats are incredibly important and deserve a lot of discussions, but the course missed the mark because of its design and execution. It was way too content-based and really didn't provide students valuable training to expand their skillset. Hopefully it could be better in the future, but as of right now, I would not recommend the course.
No, I would not recommend unless there was serious restructuring of the course.
Very scattered, did not learn much but a nice idea in principle
I think I would not recommend this course. It seems to be informative but in fact it is not and did not help me much.
This was a horrible course. I would not recommend it at all. It took up a lot of time, and you end up not learning anything. If it wasn't required, I would have never taken it.

Has great potential to be a good course because the topics are important.  Would not recommend--I didn't leave with very many takeaways.  The class could have been so modern and practical, but it wasn't.
fair
Have learnt lot of different stuff

I would summarize it that the class attempts to talk about three key areas that are impacting health but don't get enough attention: climate change, antimicrobial resistance, and obesity. I would recommend this class but I think this class needs to make further improvements before vehement recommendation.
It was a compulsory course, I probably wouldn't take it if it were optional, except for the climate change and AMR sections.
Unfortunately the course is mandatory. Students should push for this to be an online course instead.
It is an interesting course that covers a variety of topics, but the poor structure of the course was definitely an issue throughout the semester.
I wouldn't recommend this course, but unfortunately it's mandatory.
It is true that this course does cover many of the most pressing topics surrounding public health to date, but the ways in which we are assessed on our knowledge are in need of careful revisions.

I think that this course was interdisciplinary and encompassed a wide range of public health topics. However, because of the way that the work was distributed and split up and how some classes were structured, I would hesitate to strongly recommend it to another student.

This is a required course but feels very painful to take and like a waste of time. I strongly urge the professors to improve their slide organization and review the wording of their questions. Overall a complete mess of a class.
It's a lot of stuff that you may or may not care about, but you should force yourself to be interested and learn anyways

I think the subject matter is interesting and important. I was disappointed and at times frustrated with how the course was designed as it is difficult to do small group discussion and participation in a large lecture theater.
This course is recommended for all YSPH students, I would just recommend making as much of an effort to engage as you can, because the lecture environment isn't really suited to that.
I would never recommend this course. For what we pay to be here and learn, this was a huge disappointment. Not worth my time or money
Excellent.

This course was the worst class I have taken so far which is disappointing considering the topic seemed very interesting and important to public health. Breaking us up into leadership groups in a large classroom was not wise and there did not appear much or any cohesiveness between modules and professors. The multiple in class discussions/assignments were often confusing and many times the TF's also seemed confused. I do not feel like I have learned anything from this class.
I don't like it but it's mandatory.
Would not recommend in its current state even though it's required.

This course is a haphazard mishmash of all of the requirements Yale would not otherwise meet for MPH accreditation. It does a disservice to both Yale, its instructors, and its students. I would not recommend this course to another student. It was poorly run and very much a trial run of a class, and it is very clear that the trial did not go well. I would never have taken this class had I not been required to, and I feel that it was a complete waste of my time. I learned very little that I had not already been exposed to. Even more frustrating was the feeling that no exam actually tested what I had learned in class. This class was unnecessarily detailed at times (geared toward an expert in AMR, for example) in ways that were completely irrelevant to my course of study. At other times, this class was a mere survey (climate change) that simply went over facts that high schoolers in a decent environmental science class would learn, and was not fitting to an MPH degree at all. I went into this class with very low expectations, and this class failed to meet them. This class needs to be completely reworked to meet the expectations of a MPH level course at Yale.

I absolutely would not recommend this course. I understand the need to fulfill accreditation criteria and fundamentally agree with having a well-rounded education. This course, however, was another failed attempt by this program to abruptly change the previous curriculum to meet the new accreditation standards at the clear expense of the time and fiscal resources of the students in this cohort. There was no reasonable way to expect us to swallow and genuinely comprehend knowledge beyond a shallow degree on 6 distinct and poorly transitioned topics. But instead in each of the 4 modules, we were expected to know superfluous disease and vector examples, theories, and mechanisms. In climate change, why would we cover dengue fever, and cholera, and malaria on top of natural disasters, and air pollution, and vulnerable populations, etc? That extent of material could only have responsibly been covered in a semester-long course. The exact same can be said about the antimicrobial resistance and obesity modules. The only reason why I would not include the leadership "module" and communication and systems thinking special topics in that critique, is because each of those 3 was tacked on like an afterthought. I was a student who attended every lecture and prepared outside of class every week and for each module, I found the individual assessment to be unreasonably difficult, used language students who were not specializing in those topics would not understand, and today I could not recall any of that material if asked. Furthermore, when in-time feedback was given, it never felt as if the professors of this course were taking that feedback seriously. It felt more as if they were resolved to keep everything as is and "fix it" for the next cohort, but what good does that do for our education? Especially given all of the other changes made to the curriculum in the fall and all the mistakes made with those too. We now expect students in the cohort to understand structural determinants and social justice frameworks, and yet the curriculum of this program and those making choices for what that curriculum looks like in requiring courses like these in which students are not going to truly learn do poorly influence the health and long-term trajectory of success of students who are not highly privileged. There should be more intentional thought and participation from diverse students in decision-making in this program if it and its faculty ever want to move beyond a highly white, wealthy, minimally professionally experienced student population.
